overview: This subject extends on the skills provided in Introduction to Improvisation. Through practical activities in workshop-style classes, instrumentalists and singers explore musical improvisation in solo and group contexts through demonstrations, deep listening exercises and challenging performance tasks.

Tailored to suit their instrument or voice, students engage in activities that extend strategies for improvising across diverse musical styles, with a particular focus on jazz improvisation, harmonic, melodic and rhythmic tools inherent in standard jazz repertoire, and the protocols of solo and group performance in a jazz context.
This subject is designed for music students who have traditionally focused on performing notated music.
This subject is available for enrolment to students in all the Bachelor of Music Majors except Jazz and Improvisation.

necessary pre-requisite: Students must meet one of the following requisite options:
additional pre-requisite: Admission into the D-MUSIC Diploma in Music

Admission into one of the following: Composition major in the B-MUS Bachelor of Music, Interactive Composition major in the B-MUS Bachelor of Music, Musicology & Ethnomusicology major in the B-MUS Bachelor of Music, Music Studies major in the B-MUS Bachelor of Music, Performance major in the B-MUS Bachelor of Music, Performance (ANAM) major in the B-MUS Bachelor of Music

assessments.description: One 3-minute solo performance (with accompaniment) applying melodic and rhythmic concepts over harmonic progressions. 400 words (equivalent)
Compose, notate and perform a solo on a jazz standard. 800 words (equivalent)
One 3-minute performance on a jazz standard (with accompaniment). 400 words (equivalent)
Hurdle requirement:. Students must attend a minimum of 75% of all scheduled classes and performances as directed.

Semester 1.Contact hours: 18 hours, comprising one 90-minute practical class per week.

Semester 2.Contact hours: 18 hours, comprising one 90-minute practical class per week.

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
